keyTakeaways: Revolutions often devour their children—idealists become tyrants
Power corrupts through small compromises that accumulate
Propaganda can make obvious falsehoods seem true
'All animals are equal, but some are more equal than others'
The masses often enable their own oppression through ignorance and fear
summary_short: Orwell's allegory of the Russian Revolution told through a farmyard. Animals overthrow their human master, establishing equality—until the pigs gradually assume all privileges. A devastating critique of totalitarianism, relevant wherever power corrupts idealism.
summary_medium:
Why This Book Matters

Animal Farm is Orwell's satire of Stalinism, but its lessons apply to any revolution betrayed. The pigs' gradual transformation from liberators to oppressors shows how power corrupts through incremental steps.

The Revolution

Old Major's dream inspires the animals to rebel. Their principles: all animals are equal, no animal shall kill another, no animal shall drink alcohol.

The Betrayal

The pigs take leadership. Gradually, each commandment is modified. 'No animal shall sleep in a bed... with sheets.' By the end, the pigs are indistinguishable from humans.
